comment: Moving refs out of templates and rescuing orphaned refs ("iep.utm.edu" from rev 492226061)

diff.*:
Line 7: Line 7:  
Ethics has a root in Greek philosophers (the word Ethics is Greek) in Western world. In Asia, [[Confucianism]], originated from China, had wide and log-lasting influence. Chinese ethics arguments, however, include not only Confucianism. See [[Chinese Philosophy]]
 
Ethics has a root in Greek philosophers (the word Ethics is Greek) in Western world. In Asia, [[Confucianism]], originated from China, had wide and log-lasting influence. Chinese ethics arguments, however, include not only Confucianism. See [[Chinese Philosophy]]
    −
Major areas of study in ethics may be divided into 3 operational areas:<ref name="iep.utm.edu"/>
+
Major areas of study in ethics may be divided into 3 operational areas:<ref name="iep.utm.edu">http://www.iep.utm.edu/ethics/</ref>
 
* [[Meta-ethics]], about the theoretical meaning and reference of moral propositions and how their [[truth value]]s (if any) may be determined;
 
* [[Meta-ethics]], about the theoretical meaning and reference of moral propositions and how their [[truth value]]s (if any) may be determined;
 
* [[Normative ethics]], about the practical means of determining a moral course of action;
 
* [[Normative ethics]], about the practical means of determining a moral course of action;
Line 58: Line 58:  
{{Main|Mohist consequentialism}}
 
{{Main|Mohist consequentialism}}
    −
[[Mohist consequentialism]], also known as state consequentialism,<ref name="readings">{{Cite book| title = Readings in classical Chinese philosophy | year = 2005 | last =Ivanhoe | first = P.J. | last2= Van Norden | first2= Bryan William |publisher = [[Hackett Publishing]] | isbn = 978-0-87220-780-6|page=60|quote="he advocated a form of state consequentialism, which sought to maximize three basic goods: the wealth, order, and population of the state}}</ref> is an ethical theory which evaluates the moral worth of an action based on how much it contributes to the social harmony of a state.<ref name="readings"/> The ''[[Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy]]'' describes Mohist consequentialism, dating back to the 5th century BC, as "a remarkably sophisticated version based on a plurality of intrinsic goods taken as constitutive of human welfare."<ref>Fraser, Chris, "[http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/mohism/ Mohism]", ''[[The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy]]'' , Edward N. Zalta.</ref> Unlike utilitarianism, which views pleasure as a moral good, "the basic goods in Mohist consequentialist thinking are... order, material wealth, and increase in population".<ref name="Cambridge">{{Cite book| title = [[The Cambridge History of Ancient China]] | year = 1999 | last =Loewe | first = Michael | last2= Shaughnessy | first2= Edward L. |publisher = [[Cambridge University Press]] | isbn = 978-0-521-47030-8|page=761}}</ref> During [[Mozi]]'s era, war and famines were common, and population growth was seen as a moral necessity for a harmonious society. The "material wealth" of Mohist consequentialism refers to [[Maslow's hierarchy of needs|basic needs]] like shelter and clothing, and the "order" of Mohist consequentialism refers to Mozi's stance against warfare and violence, which he viewed as pointless and a threat to social stability.<ref name="Norden"/> [[Stanford University|Stanford]] [[sinologist]] [[David S. Nivison|David Shepherd Nivison]], in the ''[[The Cambridge History of Ancient China]]'', writes that the moral goods of Mohism "are interrelated: more basic wealth, then more reproduction; more people, then more production and wealth... if people have plenty, they would be good, filial, kind, and so on unproblematically."<ref name="Cambridge"/> In contrast to Bentham, Mozi did not believe that individual happiness was important, the consequences of the [[State (polity)|state]] outweigh the consequences of individual actions.<ref name="Cambridge"/>
+
[[Mohist consequentialism]], also known as state consequentialism,<ref name="readings">{{Cite book| title = Readings in classical Chinese philosophy | year = 2005 | last =Ivanhoe | first = P.J. | last2= Van Norden | first2= Bryan William |publisher = [[Hackett Publishing]] | isbn = 978-0-87220-780-6|page=60|quote="he advocated a form of state consequentialism, which sought to maximize three basic goods: the wealth, order, and population of the state}}</ref> is an ethical theory which evaluates the moral worth of an action based on how much it contributes to the social harmony of a state.<ref name="readings"/> The ''[[Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy]]'' describes Mohist consequentialism, dating back to the 5th century BC, as "a remarkably sophisticated version based on a plurality of intrinsic goods taken as constitutive of human welfare."<ref>Fraser, Chris, "[http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/mohism/ Mohism]", ''[[The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy]]'' , Edward N. Zalta.</ref> Unlike utilitarianism, which views pleasure as a moral good, "the basic goods in Mohist consequentialist thinking are... order, material wealth, and increase in population".<ref name="Cambridge">{{Cite book| title = [[The Cambridge History of Ancient China]] | year = 1999 | last =Loewe | first = Michael | last2= Shaughnessy | first2= Edward L. |publisher = [[Cambridge University Press]] | isbn = 978-0-521-47030-8|page=761}}</ref> During [[Mozi]]'s era, war and famines were common, and population growth was seen as a moral necessity for a harmonious society. The "material wealth" of Mohist consequentialism refers to [[Maslow's hierarchy of needs|basic needs]] like shelter and clothing, and the "order" of Mohist consequentialism refers to Mozi's stance against warfare and violence, which he viewed as pointless and a threat to social stability.<ref name="Norden">{{Cite book| title = Introduction to Classical Chinese Philosophy | year = 2011 | last = Van Norden | first = Bryan W. | publisher = [[Hackett Publishing]] | isbn = 978-1-60384-468-0 | page = 52}}</ref> [[Stanford University|Stanford]] [[sinologist]] [[David S. Nivison|David Shepherd Nivison]], in the ''[[The Cambridge History of Ancient China]]'', writes that the moral goods of Mohism "are interrelated: more basic wealth, then more reproduction; more people, then more production and wealth... if people have plenty, they would be good, filial, kind, and so on unproblematically."<ref name="Cambridge"/> In contrast to Bentham, Mozi did not believe that individual happiness was important, the consequences of the [[State (polity)|state]] outweigh the consequences of individual actions.<ref name="Cambridge"/>
    −
{{quote|What is the purpose of houses? It is to protect us from the wind and cold of winter, the heat and rain of summer, and to keep out robbers and thieves. Once these ends have been secured, that is all. Whatever does not contribute to these ends should be eliminated.<ref name="Norden">{{Cite book| title = Introduction to Classical Chinese Philosophy | year = 2011 | last = Van Norden | first = Bryan W. | publisher = [[Hackett Publishing]] | isbn = 978-1-60384-468-0 | page = 52}}</ref>|Mozi|''Mozi'' (5th century BC) Ch 20}}
+
{{quote|What is the purpose of houses? It is to protect us from the wind and cold of winter, the heat and rain of summer, and to keep out robbers and thieves. Once these ends have been secured, that is all. Whatever does not contribute to these ends should be eliminated.<ref name="Norden"/>|Mozi|''Mozi'' (5th century BC) Ch 20}}
